title: Increases the degree of the crime of fraudulent accosting
summary: Reclassifies the crime of fraudulent accosting from a class A misdemeanor to a class E felony.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2043

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the penal law, in relation to increasing the criminal
penalty for fraudulent accosting from
class A misdemeanor to class E felony

SUMMARY:
This bill would amend section 165.30 of the Penal Law to
increase the criminal penalty for fraudulent accosting from Class A
misdemeanor to Class E felony.

JUSTIFICATION:
Confidence games, by their very nature, fall into that
category of crimes least reported. This fact, coupled with the
difficulties in detecting many of the schemes, has proven to be a
particularly vexing problem for law enforcement.

The problem takes on added seriousness because the elderly are often
the victims and are the least likely to afford the loss of
substantial amounts of money. The apparent success of confidence
games is dramatically shown when compared, on a monetary basis, to
the highly visible crime of a bank robbery. Statewide, over $2
million a year is taken in bank robberies; however, confidence
schemes steal an equal amount of money.

Due to the misdemeanor classification of the present fraudulent
accosting provision, many con artists are encouraged to perpetuate
their schemes because they can often plea bargain to a lesser charge
and in many cases only pay a fine. The approach stage of a confidence
game, dealt with by this section of law, is a critical approach to
protecting the public from such schemes. The enactment of this
legislation will make law enforcement efforts to curb this type of
crime more effective.

FISCAL IMPLICATION:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
The first day of November after it has become a law.
